item.title: Dr. Chan
item.dc:creator: julianchangroup.com
item.content:encoded:
Dr. Julian Chan

EDUCATION
Ph.D.  Massachusetts Institute of Technology (2010)

B.Sc.  University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (2005)

PROFESSIONAL EXPERIENCE

Assistant Professor of Chemistry,  University of Ottawa (starting July 2015)

Postdoctoral Researcher II,  IBM Almaden Research Center (2012-2014)

Postdoctoral Fellow,  University of California, Berkeley (2010-2012)

EXPERTISE

Organic synthesis, Conductive polymers, Organic electronics,

Materials chemistry, Organic semiconductors, Nanomedicine

BIOGRAPHY

Julian was born and raised in Singapore. In 2001, he moved to USA to major in Chemistry at the University of Illinois. From 2005 to 2010, Julian pursued his Ph.D. in Organic Chemistry at MIT under Prof. Timothy Swager, working on the synthesis of π-conjugated macrocycles and polymers. After graduating, Julian took up a two-year postdoctoral fellowship at UC Berkeley with Prof. Dean Toste, and a subsequent appointment at IBM Almaden’s Advanced Organic Materials division. Julian will be joining the Department of Chemistry at the University of Ottawa as an Assistant Professor on July 1, 2015.

University of Ottawa

D’Iorio Hall

10 Marie Curie

Ottawa, ON, Canada

K1N 6N5

 

Phone: (613) 562-5800 ext.

E-mail: julian.chan[at]alum.mit.edu

SELECTED AWARDS

IBM Invention Achievement Award (2013)

MIT-DuPont Presidential Fellowship (2005-2006)

UIUC Departmental Highest Distinction (2005)

item.title: Home
item.dc:creator: julianchangroup.com
item.content:encoded:
Dr. Julian Chan

 Assistant Professor

 Ph.D. MIT   (2010)

 B.Sc.  UIUC (2005)

Welcome to the Chan group!

 

Our research focuses on developing novel organic materials with interesting optoelectronic, magnetic, and biological properties. The work in our laboratories involves designing and synthesizing π-conjugated organic molecules and polymers with tailorable physical properties. Some areas of application for these functional materials include organic electronics, energy, and health care.

 

Open positions

 

We have openings for motivated graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and UROPs. Interested individuals should contact Dr. Chan (julian.chan@alum.mit.edu).

item.title: Research
item.dc:creator: julianchangroup.com
item.content:encoded:
Designing novel organic materials with electronic, optical, and magnetic properties

Our research aims to discover and develop novel conductive organic materials with physical properties that are useful for optoelectronic and biomedical applications. Activities in our labs involve the synthesis of new π-conjugated organic molecules/polymers and characterization of their electronic, optical, and magnetic properties. Our work encompasses organic synthesis, polymer chemistry, materials science, physics, and nanomedicine.

 

Ongoing projects include, but not limited to: (1) organic n-type semiconductors

                                                                                 (2) organic π-radical conductors

                                                                                 (3) exotic organic superconductors

 

Organic n-type semiconductors. In this project, we will design and synthesize various electron-deficient π-conjugated structures and measure their charge mobilities in organic field-effect transistors (OFETs). We will also conduct concurrent investigations into new postpolymerization synthetic strategies for constructing these organic n-type semiconducting structures. Interdisciplinary collaborative opportunities in the area of organic bioelectronics are anticipated.

 

Organic π-radical conductors. Organic structures with unpaired electrons are known to display unique properties such as intrinsic electrical conductivity and nonlinear optical behavior. Despite this, practical applications remain challenging due to their highly reactive nature. The goal in this project is to design and synthesize stable radical-based organic structures with properties that will be useful for optoelectronic and bio-imaging applications.

 

Organic superconductors. Superconductivity is a macroscopic quantum phenomenon observed more commonly in inorganic materials than in organic ones. This exploratory project seeks to create novel organic structures in an effort to push the limit of superconducting critical temperatures (Tc). The discovery of new materials that conduct electricity without resistance at practical temperatures will have major impacts on technologies spanning electronics, energy, health care, and transportation.

 

Positions available

Graduate students, undergraduates, and postdocs interested in joining the group are welcome to e-mail Dr. Chan directly. Students will learn about multistep organic synthesis, polymers, rational materials design using structure-property relationships, and characterization techniques such as UV-vis and fluorescence spectroscopy, gel permeation chromatography, and OFET measurements, etc. Students can also look forward to exciting interdisciplinary collaborations with scientists in the physics and biomedical fields.
